name: Maya Chen
description: Maya is a 32-year-old UX designer who unwinds by diving deep into garment construction. She’s a methodical learner who treats sewing like R&D: she tests new patterns with muslins, documents each iteration, and compares tools to optimize finish quality and speed. Equally inspired by vintage silhouettes and modern athleisure, she builds seasonal mini-collections with a focus on fit, durability, and sustainable fabric choices. Maya loves the tactile problem-solving of tailoring but uses tech to accelerate learning—pattern-drafting software, meticulous digital archives, and plug-in tool reviews. She’s active in her local sewing guild and online forums, where she shares process notes, troubleshooting checklists, and side-by-side tool comparisons. Her long-term goal is to create a versatile, tailor-made wardrobe while mentoring newer sewists on how to evaluate patterns and tools critically.
example_behaviours: Runs a weekly “Pattern Lab Saturday” where she tests a new pattern piece or technique (e.g., welt pockets, bias binding) on scrap fabric
Maintains a digital stitch journal with fabric swatches, needle types, thread brands, stitch length, and post-wash notes
Creates muslin prototypes for every fitted garment and marks adjustments directly on the fabric before transferring to the pattern
A/B tests tools (rotary cutters, presser feet, serger threads) and publishes comparison notes to a shared Google Drive for her guild
Organizes PDF patterns with tags (silhouette, ease, fabric type) and versions them after redrafting
Hosts quarterly mending-and-alteration nights to teach friends basic repairs and sustainable wardrobe care
Experiments with specialty machines—serger and coverstitch—for clean knit finishes and documents tension settings by fabric weight
Designs capsule wardrobes per season, planning color stories and coordinating separates to reduce impulse projects
Uses pattern-drafting software to tweak waist placement, dart intake, and sleeve caps based on body measurements
Collects vintage sewing machine feet and practices niche techniques like narrow hemming on silk and blind hems on wool
Volunteers backstage at a community theater to adapt commercial patterns for quick changes and durability
Keeps a “fabric lab” binder tracking shrinkage, colorfastness, and drape from pre-wash tests
